executive_summary: Over the past five years, ATM manufacturers have faced a steady decline in demand that forced many manufacturers to permanently close up shop. Consumers are using cash less often than ever, making ATMs less needed in consumers' day-to-day lives. What little demand for ATMs remains is mostly being captured by imports, especially from South Korea and Mexico, as companies in these nations can leverage cheaper labor to undercut the prices of domestic manufacturers. This also puts tense price competition on the industry, compressing profit. Industry-wide revenue has been dropping at a CAGR of 3.4% over the past five years and is expected to total $354.5 million in 2023, when revenue is projected to sink 1.5%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The ATM Manufacturing industry's revenue has been falling
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The ATM Manufacturing industry's revenue has been falling at a CAGR of 3.4% over the past five years – including an estimated 1.5% drop in the current year – and is expected to total $354.5 million in 2023, with profit set to reach 5.2%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The COVID-19 Pandemic Sped Up the Industry's Downfall
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The ATM manufacturing industry has experienced a significant decline over the past five years, predominantly driven by the rise in online banking activities and credit card usage. Apps like Venmo and Apple Pay are also threatening the industry by making cash less relevant in consumers' lives, which in turn cuts demand for ATMs. The COVID-19 pandemic rapidly accelerated this decline as consumers heavily shifted to online services and contactless payment options that bypass the industry. While financial clients and other buyers brought back some revenue growth in 2021, industry revenue has yet to make a full recovery.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Manufacturers Are Beginning to Exit the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: ATMs have lost market acceptance, with manufacturing facing declining demand for their machines amid digitization and the shrinking role of cash in consumers' day-to-day lives. Independent ATM operators, particularly small retailers, have little incentive to replace their existing machines due to the low revenue generated compared to the cost of the ATMs. Dropping demand has brought contraction to the industry, forcing many manufacturers to close up shop permanently.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The ATM Manufacturing industry's revenue is expected to decline
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The ATM Manufacturing industry's revenue is expected to decline at a CAGR of 0.4% to $346.7 million over the five years to 2028, when profit is estimated to slightly expand to 5.3%.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Cash Continues to Becomes Less Relevant
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Demand for ATMs is set to continue dropping through the end of 2028 as consumers increasingly opt for payment apps, mobile wallets and credit and debit cards for their day-to-day purchases. The percentage of business conducted online and e-commerce sales are both set to steadily rise over the next five years, indicating growing consumer preference for online shopping platforms like Amazon, which don't have options for cash payments. As cash becomes less relevant in consumer's lives, fewer stores will have incentive to purchase ATMs and revenue will continue to decline.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: New PCI DSS Requirements Will Likely Temper Losses
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Payment Card Industry Security Standards Council (PCI SSC) has recently updated the Data Security Standards (DSS), which are mandatory regulations ATM owners and operators need to follow. By 2025, all ATMs will need to be using software and firmware that uses TR31 Phase 3 key blocks, which provide a higher level of encryption for customers' PINs and other financial information. While demand for ATMs will still fall through the end of 2028, host processors will no longer support ATMs without the proper equipment after the deadline. This means banking institutions and independent operators that wish to continue offering an ATM will need to update their machines. This boost is set to temper losses, but revenue is expected to continue declining as ATM owners opt for lower-cost parts to retrofit their machines and bring them up to current standards, rather than fully replacing them with new models.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Imports Lessen and Give US Manufacturers Some Much-Needed Breathing Room
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Imports currently account for over half of all demand in the United States and pose a significant threat to domestic ATM manufacturers. The value of the US dollar in relation to other currencies, as measured by the trade-weighted index (TWI), is set to steadily decline over the next five years. A depreciating dollar makes US goods more affordable and encourages purchases of domestic ATMs. While imports will likely still account for most ATM sales in the United States, domestic manufacturers can temper losses by reclaiming some local clients.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures automated teller machines (ATMs). An ATM is a computerized telecommunications device that provides the clients of financial institutions with access to financial transaction functionality without the need for a cashier or teller.

mixed_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: medium - steady

key_trends: The ATM manufacturing industry has experienced a significant decline over the past five years
ATMs have lost market acceptance, with manufacturing facing declining demand for their machines

market_segmentation.segment_description: Independent ATMs are not manufactured for use with a specific bank or credit union and are placed in areas like shopping malls, gas stations, restaurants and other areas with high foot traffic. These ATMs typically have less functionality than bank ATMs, so they're usually more affordable to make.

Smaller regional banks buy ATMs for many of the same reasons large institutions do but purchase machines less often and on a smaller scale. Many smaller banks will only replace their ATMs when new regulations emerge that legally require them to ensure their machines are using the most modern firmware and software that adequately protects their customers' data. Regional banks with limited labor resources often buy drive-up ATMs, which allow them to extend their operating hours with fewer employees on-site.

This segment includes the top ten banking clients for the industry that buy ATMs to provide their customers with a self-service option to manage their finances. Big banks have focused on enhancing their ATM user experience by seeking more features, like cardless withdrawals, mobile app integration and personalized settings, providing consumers with greater convenience and control. The top three financial clients for ATM manufacturers are JP Morgan Chase, Bank of America and Wells Fargo. These banking giants have immense power over manufacturers as they often buy ATMs in bulk and can demand significant discounts.

products_and_services.product_description: Independent ATMs are not manufactured for use with a specific bank or credit union and are placed in areas like shopping malls, gas stations, restaurants and other areas with high foot traffic. These ATMs typically have less functionality than bank ATMs, so they're usually more affordable to make.

Replacement parts sold apart from a complete terminal, not including software, generate a small portion of the industry's revenue because of their lower price point. ATMs are expensive and have a long useful life, so customers will generally seek to repair existing ATMs when possible. In addition, new microchip technology requirements may drive demand for parts as banks and retailers have sought to retrofit existing machines to bring them up to compliance rather than purchasing new units. This segment is expected to rise as a share of revenue over the next five years as lackluster demand encourages buyers to fix older machines instead of replacing them entirely.

The industry also manufactures bank-branded ATMs, including interior and drive-up machines located in or outside of banks. Interior ATMs are manufactured for use in bank lobbies, while drive-up ATMs are made to be attached to the outside of a bank for quick and convenient access on any day and at any time. Generally, banks and credit unions offer unlimited withdrawals from their own ATMs with no extra fee. Many customers choose to use on-site ATMs as a quick alternative to waiting in line for a teller, and banks can help cut labor costs by offering these self-service options.

tier_1_suppliers: Computer Peripheral Manufacturing in the US
Plastic & Resin Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Electric Power Transmission in the US
Industrial Machinery & Equipment Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_buyers: Accommodation and Food Services in the US
Arts, Entertainment and Recreation in the US
Copier & Office Equipment Wholesaling in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: A key determinant is the demand from commercial banks, largely influenced by the volatility of equity markets which impacts their after-tax return on deposits. Bank customers' confidence in the economy also affects demand, determining the interest in savings, checking, and money market accounts. This in turn influences the usage of ATMs.

Consumer confidence has a significant role in driving the number of bank deposits, which determines demand for ATMs. A downturn in equity markets can encourage more people to deposit in the bank, fueling ATM demand. Heightened consumer spending ups the frequency of which consumers use ATMs, sparking demand for manufacturing.
Customer preference for easy, secure, reliable and swift service also impacts banking demand.
The retail industry and online banking likewise affect ATM manufacturing demand, as retail businesses install white label ATMs to cut costs and broaden their consumer base.
Regulation is another big factor for demand, as each new law generates demand as companies are required to update their ATMs to meet particular standards, like the ADA or PCI DSS.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Exports of ATMs Aren't Focused to Any Nations
international_trade_points.trade_description: While South Korea and Mexico are the top destinations for US-made ATMs, the industry's exports are varied and widely bought worldwide. This protects the industry from volatility that trade disputes can bring, as manufacturers aren't reliant on political stability with any given country.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The COVID-19 Pandemic Sped Up a Decline in Exports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Exports of ATMs have been steadily declining since 2016, but the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic brought supply chain issues and a suspension of demand that severely cut exports. Exports began to rise again in 2022 but are still less than half the value at the beginning of the current period.

Declining demand for ATMs as cash becomes less relevant has made it more difficult for overseas buyers to justify importing expensive US ATMs. This slump in export activity has led US manufacturers to focus on domestic markets.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports are threatening US manufacturers despite volatility
international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports have fluctuated through the COVID-19 pandemic as supply chain disruptions made it more difficult to transport ATMs. Imported ATMs are highly sought-after by US buyers, as competitors in South Korea and other nations can leverage cheaper labor and more accessible inputs to undercut the prices of US-made ATMs.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Price is becoming a critical base of competition
international_trade_points.trade_description: As demand for ATMs continues to decline, price is becoming an even more critical base of competition. Imports have significantly climbed over the past five years and account for over half of all demand in the US.

international_trade_points.trade_title: A declining TWI will likely lessen import penetration
international_trade_points.trade_description: The value of the US dollar in relation to foreign currencies, as measured by the trade-weighted index (TWI), is set to decline over the five years to 2028. This will make US-made ATMs comparatively less expensive to foreign substitutes, promoting domestic manufacturers.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast continues to be the leading region in ATM installations, primarily because of its massive population. Because of the high average age, consumers in the Southeast also have a higher preference for using cash instead of digital alternatives. Most ATM imports come from South Korea, so manufacturers in the Southeast are more protected from imports because of the higher transportation costs to ship machines across the US.

The Mid-Atlantic and the Great Lakes regions play a significant role in the distribution of ATMs. Accessing key markets in the New England region is important, but the region's high costs of operation make it more practical for ATM manufacturers to construct their machines in the Great Lakes or Mid-Atlantic region before shipping them north.

The Mid-Atlantic and the Great Lakes regions play a significant role in the distribution of ATMs. Accessing key markets in the New England region is important, but the region's high costs of operation make it more practical for ATM manufacturers to construct their machines in the Great Lakes or Mid-Atlantic region before shipping them north.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Under the EFTA, ATM manufacturers must adhere to rules related to transaction disclosures, error resolution procedures and consumer liability for unauthorized transactions. This helps ensure security when handling banking information.

ATM manufacturers are subject to BSA regulations, which aim to prevent money laundering and terrorist financing. These regulations require manufacturers to establish anti-money laundering (AML) programs and report certain transactions to government authorities.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS)
regulations_points.regulation_description: ATM manufacturers must adhere to PCI DSS requirements to safeguard cardholder data, ensuring secure transactions and protecting against data breaches. The newest update to these standards will require all operational ATMs to be up-to-date with firmware and software that uses TR31 Phase 3 key blocks by January 1, 2025.

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and other government entities require ATM manufacturers to properly treat their waste. Hazardous material treatment, waste disposal and energy efficiency initiatives can bring elevated operating costs for the industry.

The 2012 ADA includes a section titled Standards for Accessible Design, which requires ATM manufacturers to meet include audio output, user-controlled volume and input controls (keypads). The ADA also requires that at least one talking ATM be made available to customers at every ATM location to improve accessibility.

barriers_points.barrier_description: New ATM manufacturers will need to navigate moderate regulatory oversight related to the handling of private banking information, minimum standards for firmware and software and the treatment of waste created in the manufacturing process.
The substantial initial investment in production facilities, distribution networks and research and development can deter entrants with limited capital from joining the industry.

The presence of large incumbent manufacturers with brand recognition, unique products, economies of scale and established contracts with key buyers makes it difficult for new ATM manufacturers to differentiate themselves in a competitive market.

ATM manufacturers rely on skilled employees capable of navigating regulations and conducting extensive research and development. These workers command higher wages and can be expensive to attract, especially for new manufacturers.

basis_points.basis_title: Internal competition on price and quality
basis_points.basis_description: ATM manufacturers compete primarily on an internal basis, most notably on the price and quality of the products. Recently, price competition has intensified as many foreign competitors have expanded their market share in the United States.

The ability of manufacturers to integrate new and existing technology into their ATMs is highly competitive because clients want to have the most innovative machines to attract a large number of users, resulting in higher revenue.

basis_points.basis_title: Providing end-to-end solutions and customer relations
basis_points.basis_description: The ability of manufacturers to provide and support a total end-to-end solution is important for clients. Many major manufacturers provide installation and maintenance services throughout the life of an ATM, which improves their relationship with the client. The quality of a manufacturer's customer relations is also a point of internal competition.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry is highly concentrated, with the top two companies accounting for nearly three-quarters of the US market. The top companies regularly buy out competitors.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Economies of scale support large manufacturers
concentration_points.concentration_description: The existing dominance of NCR and Diebold Nixdorf allows them to leverage their higher position to secure key contracts with national financial institutions. These contracts enable large manufacturers to acquire smaller companies, expanding their market share and upping their production capacity.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases make up an estimated 48.7% of revenue in 2023
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Manufacturers depend on several upstream industries that produce the industry's key inputs, like firmware and circuitry. As an assembly-oriented manufacturing industry, purchases of finished components are essential for ATM manufacturers to create their products. ATM manufacturers' reliance on purchasing finished products allows them to avoid costly capital investment in specialized machinery that only creates one or two components.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Many components purchased from third parties
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Many of the components used as inputs in ATMs are purchased from third parties, reducing the need for large-scale automation of the production process by ATM manufacturers.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Heavy spending on labor for R&D and maintenance
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Manufacturers spend heavily on labor for the purposes of research and development and maintenance. Even during periods of sluggish new unit sales, the industry must maintain a service workforce to uphold obligations to past customers.
In 2023, for every $1.00 spent on labor, the average ATM manufacturer will invest an estimated $0.02 on capital investments.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patents and patent concentration
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified. The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served by incumbent operators.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Imports play a major role in the industry, accounting for nearly three-quarters of all demand in the United States. Domestic ATM manufacturers can reclaim local demand and lift revenue as exchange rates and supply chain issues cause imports to become less affordable to US buyers. Imports have significantly risen over the past five years as companies overseas leverage cheaper labor and proximity to upstream industries to undercut the prices of US ATM manufacturers. The COVID-19 pandemic and following widespread inflation have made trade exceptionally volatile over the past five years.

Updated regulations can bring a spike in demand for ATM manufacturers as existing machines are replaced by new models that are compliant with current standards. The industry enjoyed massive growth in 2012 and 2013 following the rollout of new Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) mandates that required ATMs to be refitted to be more accessible. New Payment Card Industry Data Security Standards (PCI DSS) have recently been released and will drive demand for ATMs as owners aim to ensure their machines are up-to-date.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Consumer behavior drives demand for changes
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Consumer behavior primarily drives demand for changes in ATM technology, and these changes have recently accelerated following consumer demand for more efficient and accessible banking solutions.
Many companies are upping their investment in R&D as a way to strengthen client loyalty and gain new contracts.

Over the five years to 2023, manufacturers have worked with financial institutions to identify and implement ways to create a more engaging experience, resulting in new solutions that cater to consumer preference for the use of similar technologies across all their devices.

Manufacturers have also incorporated touch screen technology and user-defined personalization, which enable their consumers to efficiently interact with their banks, while maintaining a personal touch.

Recently, multifunctional ATMs have started being developed in the United States. These machines will enable customers to not only perform regular banking activities, but also give them the ability to buy and print concert tickets, donate to charitable organizations, pay speeding fines, buy prepaid gift cards and file taxes.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Imports have risen substantially over the past five years to account for nearly two-thirds of US ATM demand.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: The industry is loosely connected to the performance of banks, which is cyclical.

FAQs.question: The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) requires ATM manufacturers to include features like audio output and user-controlled volume and input controls (keypads). It also requires at least one talking ATM at every ATM location. Does your company comply with these ADA requirements?
FAQs.answer: The 2012 ADA includes a section titled Standards for Accessible Design, which requires ATM manufacturers to meet include audio output, user-controlled volume and input controls (keypads). The ADA also requires that at least one talking ATM be made available to customers at every ATM location to improve accessibility.

FAQs.question: Does your company receive any public or private industry assistance?
FAQs.answer: ATM manufacturers don't receive any form of public assistance. The National ATM Council (NAC) and the ATM Industry Association (ATMIA) are the industry's top advocates in the legislative process, helping support the industry by managing regulatory oversight. These organizations also provide members with market research, networking events and educational workshops.

FAQs.question: Is your company located near important suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Locating near ports may provide a company easier access to electronic inputs, which are mostly manufactured abroad.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing heavily in R&D to meet changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: The industry tends to follow standards crafted by banking groups, rather than engaging in its own development.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology?
FAQs.answer: EMV card-reading ATMs, a new industry standard, has driven some demand for new ATMs.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: The industry may have difficulty controlling wage costs due to the volatility of sales.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to comply with new environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: There are no environmental standards that specifically relate to ATM manufacturing.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: The industry is subject to the basic occupational health and safety standards that pertain to companies across the manufacturing sector.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your customers renew their contracts?
FAQs.answer: Major banks make major ATM purchases, and retaining one as a customer can be a major advantage for a manufacturer.

FAQs.question: What ongoing financing challenges does your company face?
FAQs.answer: Major purchases from commercial banks make the industry very volatile, which can cause challenges in cash flow.

FAQs.question: How quickly can you adopt new technology? How much of your revenue goes toward research and development?
FAQs.answer: ATM manufacturers that can quickly incorporate new technologies and software are able to keep up with consumer trends better.

FAQs.question: Are your products competitively priced? How do you compete with imports?
FAQs.answer: ATM manufacturers face extremely fierce price competition. Failure to implement effective cost controls can quickly reduce market share.

FAQs.question: In what export markets do you operate? How can you expand your reach in those markets?
FAQs.answer: The majority of growth in ATM demand is expected to occur outside the United States. Manufacturers with a strong presence in growing economies will outperform their competitors.

FAQs.question: How do you compete with online sales? What technologies have you invested in to make your products more appealing?
FAQs.answer: As consumers increasingly shop online, demand for online payment services increases to the detriment of cash.

FAQs.question: Does the usage of your machines increase with rising consumer spending? How can you capitalize on increase consumer spending?
FAQs.answer: As consumer spending grows, new financial accounts are created and the flow of money increases, creating a need for more financial transactions.

FAQs.question: Do you have long-term supply contracts with commercial banks? How can you upgrade your machines to command a higher price point?
FAQs.answer: The majority of industry revenue is supplied by direct sales to commercial banks. Banks purchase ATMs to place within on-site banking locations or off-site public locations to serve the needs of their customers in making basic transactions.
